title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: Create satisficing tables R formula way. objective tablespan provide “good enough” approach creating tables leveraging R’s formulas. tablespan builds awesome packages openxlsx gt, allows tables created tablespan exported following formats: Excel (using openxlsx) HTML (using gt) LaTeX (using gt) RTF (using gt)

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: install tablespan CRAN use: development version tablespan can installed GitHub :
code: install.packages("tablespan") library(remotes) remotes::install_github("jhorzek/tablespan")

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: R large set great packages allow create export tables look exactly like envisioned. However, sometimes may just need good-enough table easy create share others. tablespan can help. Let’s assume want share following table: don’t want share table - variable names bit technical table need spanners summarizing columns. , want share table looks something like : tablespan allows us create table single formula.
code: library(dplyr) data("mtcars")  summarized_table <- mtcars |>   group_by(cyl, vs) |>   summarise(N = n(),             mean_hp = mean(hp),             sd_hp = sd(hp),             mean_wt = mean(wt),             sd_wt = sd(wt)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'cyl'. You can override using the `.groups` #> argument.  print(summarized_table) #> # A tibble: 5 × 7 #> # Groups:   cyl [3] #>     cyl    vs     N mean_hp sd_hp mean_wt  sd_wt #>   <dbl> <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1     4     0     1    91   NA       2.14 NA     #> 2     4     1    10    81.8 21.9     2.30  0.598 #> 3     6     0     3   132.  37.5     2.76  0.128 #> 4     6     1     4   115.   9.18    3.39  0.116 #> 5     8     0    14   209.  51.0     4.00  0.759 |                   | Horse Power |   Weight  | | Cylinder | Engine | Mean  |  SD | Mean | SD | | -------- | ------ | ----- | --- | ---- | -- | |                   |                         |

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: tablespan, table headers defined formula. example, cyl ~ mean_hp + sd_hp defines table cyl row names mean_hp sd_hp columns: Note row names (cyl) separate block left.
code: library(tablespan) tablespan(data = summarized_table,           formula = cyl ~ mean_hp + sd_hp) #>                          #>  | cyl | mean_hp sd_hp | #>  | --- - ------- ----- | #>  | 4   | 91            | #>  | 4   | 81.8    21.87 | #>  | 6   | 131.67  37.53 | #>  | ... | ...     ...   |

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: Spanners defined using braces spanner names. example, following defines spanner mean_hp sd_hp name Horsepower: cyl ~ (Horsepower = mean_hp + sd_hp): Spanners can also nested:
code: tablespan(data = summarized_table,           formula = cyl ~ (Horsepower = mean_hp + sd_hp)) #>                             #>  |     | Horsepower       | #>  | cyl | mean_hp    sd_hp | #>  | --- - ---------- ----- | #>  | 4   | 91               | #>  | 4   | 81.8       21.87 | #>  | 6   | 131.67     37.53 | #>  | ... | ...        ...   | tablespan(data = summarized_table,           formula = cyl ~ (Horsepower = (Mean = mean_hp) + (SD  = sd_hp))) #>                             #>  |     | Horsepower       | #>  |     | Mean       SD    | #>  | cyl | mean_hp    sd_hp | #>  | --- - ---------- ----- | #>  | 4   | 91               | #>  | 4   | 81.8       21.87 | #>  | 6   | 131.67     37.53 | #>  | ... | ...        ...   |

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: Variable names R data.frame often technical (e.g., mean_hp sd_hp). sharing table, may want replace names. example , may want replace mean_hp sd_hp “Mean” “SD”. tablespan renaming variables achieved new_name:old_name. example, cyl ~ (Horsepower = Mean:mean_hp + SD:sd_hp) renames mean_hp Mean sd_hp SD:
code: tablespan(data = summarized_table,           formula = cyl ~ (Horsepower = Mean:mean_hp + SD:sd_hp)) #>                             #>  |     | Horsepower       | #>  | cyl | Mean       SD    | #>  | --- - ---------- ----- | #>  | 4   | 91               | #>  | 4   | 81.8       21.87 | #>  | 6   | 131.67     37.53 | #>  | ... | ...        ...   |

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: combination row names, spanners, renaming variables allows creating full table:
code: library(dplyr) library(tablespan) data("mtcars")  summarized_table <- mtcars |>   group_by(cyl, vs) |>   summarise(N = n(),             mean_hp = mean(hp),             sd_hp = sd(hp),             mean_wt = mean(wt),             sd_wt = sd(wt)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'cyl'. You can override using the `.groups` #> argument.  tbl <- tablespan(data = summarized_table,                  formula = Cylinder:cyl + Engine:vs ~                    N +                    (`Horse Power` = Mean:mean_hp + SD:sd_hp) +                    (`Weight` = Mean:mean_wt + SD:sd_wt),                  title = "Motor Trend Car Road Tests",                  subtitle = "A table created with tablespan",                  footnote = "Data from the infamous mtcars data set.") tbl #> Motor Trend Car Road Tests #> A table created with tablespan #>                                                          #>  |                 |     Horse Power       Weight      | #>  | Cylinder Engine | N   Mean        SD    Mean   SD   | #>  | -------- ------ - --  ----------- ----- ------ ---- | #>  | 4        0      | 1   91                2.14        | #>  | 4        1      | 10  81.8        21.87 2.3    0.6  | #>  | 6        0      | 3   131.67      37.53 2.76   0.13 | #>  | ...      ...    | ... ...         ...   ...    ...  | #> Data from the infamous mtcars data set.

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: Tables created tablespan can now translated xlsx tables openxlsx using as_excel function:
code: # as_excel creates an openxlsx workbook wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl)  # Save the workbook as an xlsx file: # openxlsx::saveWorkbook(wb, #                        file = "cars.xlsx",  #                        overwrite = TRUE)

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: tablespan provides limited styling options, elements can adjusted. example, may want print elements bold format numbers differently. tablespan, styling happens translating table openxlsx workbook as_excel. end, tablespan provides styles argument.

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: easiest way customize tables change default color scheme. function tbl_styles provides control elements table, many cases style_color may sufficient. following creates table teal-colored backgrounds title, header, row names:  Similarly, dark background can defined follows:
code: wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl,                 styles = style_color(primary_color = "#008080"))  # Save the workbook as an xlsx file: # openxlsx::saveWorkbook(wb, #                        file = "cars.xlsx",  #                        overwrite = TRUE) wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl,                 styles = style_color(primary_color = "#000000"))  # Save the workbook as an xlsx file: # openxlsx::saveWorkbook(wb, #                        file = "cars.xlsx",  #                        overwrite = TRUE)

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: Let’s assume want mean_hp values value ≥100\geq 100 printed bold. end, first create new style object using openxlsx: Next, create cell style tablespan: Note specify indices rows want bold column name item. Finally, pass style part list as_excel:
code: bold <- openxlsx::createStyle(textDecoration = "bold") hp_ge_100 <- cell_style(rows = which(summarized_table$mean_hp >= 100),                          colnames = "mean_hp",                          style = bold,                         gridExpand = FALSE) # as_excel creates an openxlsx workbook wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl,                 styles = tbl_styles(cell_styles = list(hp_ge_100)))  # Save the workbook as an xlsx file: # openxlsx::saveWorkbook(wb, #                        file = "cars.xlsx",  #                        overwrite = TRUE)

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: tablespan also allows formatting specific data types. Let’s assume want round doubles 3 instead default 2 digits. end, use create_data_styles function, specify (1) function checks data type want style (.double) (2) style columns match style:
code: double_style <- create_data_styles(double = list(test = is.double,                                                   style = openxlsx::createStyle(numFmt = "0.000"))) wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl, styles = tbl_styles(data_styles = double_style))  # Save the workbook as an xlsx file: # openxlsx::saveWorkbook(wb, #                        file = "cars.xlsx",  #                        overwrite = TRUE)

what: Exporting to HTML, LaTeX, and RTF
title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: Tables created tablespan can also exported gt allows saving HTML, LaTeX, RTF file. end, simply call as_gt table:
code: # Translate to gt: gt_tbl <- as_gt(tbl = tbl) gt_tbl

previous_headings: Exporting to HTML, LaTeX, and RTF
title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: gt package provides wide range functions adapt style table created as_gt. instance, opt_stylize adds pre-defined style entire table:  adapting gt object, important detail keep mind: ensure table spanner unique ID, tablespan create IDs differ text shown spanner. demonstrate , Let’s assume want add spanner Horse Power Weight: throw error spanner IDs different spanner labels. get spanner IDs, use gt::tab_info():  IDs spanners can found bottom. add another spanner Horse Power Weight, use IDs:
code: gt_tbl |>    gt::opt_stylize(style = 6,                   color = 'gray') gt_tbl |>    gt::tab_spanner(label = "New Spanner",                    spanners = c("Horse Power", "Weight")) #> Error in `gt::tab_spanner()`: #> ! One or more spanner ID(s) supplied in `spanners` (Horse Power and #>   Weight), for the new spanner with the ID `New Spanner` doesn't belong to any #>   existing spanners. gt_tbl |>    gt::tab_info() gt_tbl |>    gt::tab_spanner(label = "New Spanner",                    spanners = c("__BASE_LEVEL__Horse Power",                                 "__BASE_LEVEL__Weight"))

title: Create Satisficing Excel, HTML, LaTeX, and RTF Tables using a Simple Formula
text: Using 1 left hand side formula creates table without row names. example, 1 ~ (Horsepower = Mean:mean_hp + SD:sd_hp) defines

Translating data to tibble  wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl)  # saveWorkbook(wb, "iris.xlsx")  # To apply a custom style to some elements use the styles argument. The following # applies the "bold" style to the rows 1-5 of the Sepal.Length column and # the rows 9-10 of the Petal.Width column. bold <- openxlsx::createStyle(textDecoration = "bold")  wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl,                styles = tbl_styles(cell_styles = list(cell_style(rows = 1:5,                                                                 colnames = "Sepal.Length",                                                                 style = bold),                                                      cell_style(rows = 9:10,                                                                 colnames = "Petal.Width",                                                                 style = bold)))) # saveWorkbook(wb, "iris.xlsx")  # The main use case for tablespan is when you already have a summarized table # that you now want to share using xlsx. The following shows an example using # the dplyr package:  # First summarize the data: summarized_table <- mtcars |>   group_by(cyl, vs) |>   summarise(N = n(),             mean_hp = mean(hp),             sd_hp = sd(hp),             mean_wt = mean(wt),             sd_wt = sd(wt)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'cyl'. You can override using the `.groups` #> argument.  # Now, we want to create a table, where we show the grouping variables # as row names and also create spanners for the horse power (hp) and the # weight (wt) variables: tbl <- tablespan(data = summarized_table,           formula = Cylinder:cyl + Engine:vs ~             N +             (`Horse Power` = Mean:mean_hp + SD:sd_hp) +             (`Weight` = Mean:mean_wt + SD:sd_wt),           title = "Motor Trend Car Road Tests",           subtitle = "A table created with tablespan",           footnote = "Data from the infamous mtcars data set.")  wb <- as_excel(tbl = tbl)  # Create the excel table: # openxlsx::saveWorkbook(wb, #                        file = "cars.xlsx", overwrite = TRUE)
